response.answer_text: The story starts 77 years ago. Dusk was falling on March 13, 1940. In London’s Caxton Hall, a meeting of the Royal Central Asian Society and the East India Association was in progress. Among the attendees was a 40 years old Indian man. As the conference drew to an end, he pulled out a revolver from his coat and rapidly fired two shots at one of the British speakers – Michael Francis O’Dwyer, the former governor of Punjab, India.[1][2]  Born on December 26, 1899, at the village of Sunam in Punjab’s Sangrur district, Our had been to Africa, Europe and the Americas - He’d been in the Army, worked his way up in life, done some odd jobs - earned a living and respect and was finally settled in London - he was regarded and liked in his community. Interestingly he even worked as an extra in blockbuster films like Elephant Boy (1937) and The Four Feathers (1939)[3][4]  (Man in the middle) Not bad for someone born in a small village in Punjab, who had lost his parents at an early age and grew up in an orphanage in Amritsar since the age of 5.  Some called him Frank Brazil - others remembered him by the name he had tattooed in his arms Ram Mohammad Singh Azad[2][3]. Life was good - everything was fine. There was just one issue - Our 40 years old man had not celebrated the festival of Baisakhi since the age of 19. Not because he was living in foreign lands but because he didn’t feel like celebrating. After 21 long years finally he got an opportunity to do something about it. On 13th March 1940, just 6 months since the World War II had officially started and about 7 years before India won her Independence, he decided to take part in a meeting organised by the Royal Central Asian Society and the East India Association in the historic building of Caxton Hall, not very far from the British Parliament[4].  He polished his shoes, wore his best suit and went there with a disarming smile.  At Caxton Hall, after the meeting concluded, he stood up calmly - walked up to the podium - took out the revolver that he hide in his overcoat - and aimed at a man sitting on the dias.[5] He shot Sir Michael Francis O'Dwyer, the former Lieutenant Governor of Punjab, and the guest of honor for the evening, twice.[6]  He did not try to flee or resist arrest and was immediately taken into custody. He was duly arrested and held in Brixton prison.[7] After a quick trial, he was found guilty and sentenced to death, he was hanged on July 31, 1940 at London’s Pentonville Prison and buried within the prison grounds.[8]  Now the question is why did he do this? The year was 1919 on 13th April - while a 19 year old he, was serving water as a volunteer, to a group of protestors and pilgrims in a park in Amritsar - he saw a British Colonel come in with 50 of his men and pump bullets indiscriminately at the 10000 unarmed and helpless men, women and children.[9] As the people tried to escape the bullets by climbing the walls or jumping into a well, the soldiers kept firing till they ran out of ammunition[10] Over 1000 died - many inside a well where they had jumped to protect themselves from the bullets - many more were injured. Along with them was injured the pride, dignity and honour of a nation which was forced to remain a meek spectator to this inglorious chapter of colonial degeneracy. It was Baisakhi that day, the festival of songs and happiness - a festival which took away the innocence of this 19 year old.  Since that day, he decided to invest every remaining minute in his life to avenge the humiliation of his people. A revenge he finally took 21 years later. Today, many remember him as Shaheed Sardar Udham Singh.[11]  He did this all for the sake of freedom A freedom, he laid his life for - a freedom, that we all enjoy, today.  P.S : In 1974, his remains were exhumed and repatriated to India before being cremated at his birthplace, Sunam village in Punjab. His ashes were then scattered in the Satluj river, the same river in which the ashes of Bhagat Singh, Rajguru and Sukhdev had been scattered. Thank you for reading.
